Overlooked in budget discussion (6): As share of GDP, US defense spending very high by global standards but LOW by historic US standards.
Overlooked in budget discussion (5): Which government spending (i.e. infrastructure, R&D) produces high LONG-RUN multipliers.
Overlooked in budget discussion (4): How attitudes toward govt change as higher % of revenues go to entitlements, less to infrastructure etc
Overlooked in budget discussion (3): How much rising health care costs matter above and beyond aging of the population.
Overlooked in budget discussion (2): Role of state, local spending. It's almost 40% of all govt spending in US and tends to offset stimulus.
Overlooked in budget discussion (1): How cheap it is for the govt to borrow. Debt rising but interest-to-GDP declining. http://t.co/MJY4tMrB

@Redistrict: I'll stick with the 538 forecast in OH. I disagree that the early voting data there provides much reason to doubt the polls.
@Redistrict: And inferences from early voting numbers will be much fuzzier when we're guessing about party ID of voters.
@Redistrict: We know a lot more about how polls work (they work well) than about what changes in early voting patterns tell us.
@Redistrict: (ii) It tends to exaggerate the changes a LOT if you treat Dem counties as tantamount to Dem voters.
@Redistrict: My problems are (i) not self-evident it's bad for Obama that he has an advantage, but less of an advantage vs 08. (1/2)
@Redistrict @Taniel: In states with higher-quality data, generally seems to be story of GOP early voting going up more than Dem going down.
@Redistrict @Taniel: You may be right. It's very confusing. But there may also be some under-reporting or slow reporting.
@Redistrict @Taniel: Which seems consistent with some reversion to the mean since Romney's ground game better than McCain's.
@Redistrict @Taniel: Maybe R counties have increased at a slightly faster pace, but still turning out voters at a lower rate than D ones
@Redistrict @Taniel: Sure, but looks like Cuyahoga has had an increase from 08.
@Redistrict @ElectProject: Yeah. They say 249,403 by mail. (http://t.co/002ZbElt) + 42,511 in person. (http://t.co/hWuopnbC)
@Redistrict @ElectProject: Cuyahoga now says 250K mail ballots + 50K in-person. State says 250K total. But I may be missing something.
@Redistrict @ElectProject: Other issue is that I think state's spreadsheet may lag behind Cuyahoga County's reporting.
@Redistrict: What I'd want to know is: what did OH polls in '08 say Obama's edge in early voting was vs. what do the polls say this year?
@Redistrict: We DON'T know much about how early vote turnout maps to Election Day turnout. We'll need a few more years of data for that.
@Redistrict: But seems like there is less of a drop-off in OH than other states, consistent with Obama's polls holding up better there.
@Redistrict: What we know for sure is that Dem counties turned out a higher share of their voters early than GOP counties.
